# 1.2 - Factors, Multiples & Prime Factorization {.unnumbered}

Have you ever had to split something up evenly ‚Äî like slices of pizza or players on a team? That‚Äôs really what {{< glink factors >}} are about: dividing numbers into equal parts.

In this lesson, you‚Äôll learn how to:

  - Spot factors and {{< glink multiples >}}.

  - Tell if a number is {{< glink prime number >}} or {{< glink composite number >}}.

  - Break numbers into their basic building blocks using a {{< glink factor tree >}}.

You‚Äôll use these skills again and again ‚Äî from simplifying fractions to solving equations.

::: {.callout-note icon=false title="üéØ Objectives"}
- [ ] I can find the factors and multiples of integers
- [ ] I can tell if a number is prime or composite
- [ ] I can break numbers into prime factors using a factor tree
:::

::: {.callout-note icon=false title="üìö Vocabulary"}
{{< glink composite number >}}, {{< glink factor >}}, {{< glink factor tree >}}, {{< glink multiple >}}, {{< glink prime factorization >}}, {{< glink prime number >}}
:::

## üî• Warm-Up

1. List all the whole-number factors of 12.

2. Find a multiple of 7 that is less than 50.

3. Is 11 a prime number? How do you know?

---

## üë• Learn Together

### 1.2.1 - What Are Factors?

A {{< glink factor >}} of a number is a whole number that divides it evenly ‚Äî with no {{< glink remainder >}}.

**Example:**

The factors of 12 are: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6 and 2

That‚Äôs because:

1 √ó 12 = 12

2 √ó 6 = 12

3 √ó 4 = 12

:::{.callout-note icon=false appearance="simple" collapse=true title="üß† Can a number have just one factor?"}
Only one number does: **1**. It only has itself as a factor and so it is neither prime nor composite!
:::

---

### 1.2.2 - What Are Multiples?

A {{< glink multiple >}} is what you get when you multiply a number by 1, 2, 3, 4‚Ä¶

**Example:**

Here are the first few multiples of 5: 

$5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, ...$

Multiples are useful when finding common denominators or common multiples later in algebra.

**Where have we seen this before?**

Multiples show up all over the place. When you skip count, you are using multiples. In the previous lesson, we used multiples to constuct number lines! 

**Example:**

Here is a number line that shows multiples of three.
![](/images/Unit_1/Lesson_2/skip_count_by_3.png)

---

### 1.2.3 - Prime vs. Composite

A **prime number** has only 2 factors: 1 and itself.

Examples: 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13...

A **composite number** has more than 2 factors.

Examples: 4, 6, 8, 9, 10...

:::{.callout-tip .realworld-box icon=false title="üåç In the Real World"}
Prime numbers play a big role in **encryption**, which keeps your data safe when you shop or message online.
:::

---

### 1.2.4 - Prime Factorization and Factor Trees

Every number can be broken into a **product of prime numbers** ‚Äî sort of like breaking a LEGO¬Æ sculpture into individual bricks. These prime factors are the basic building blocks of all whole numbers.

We use **factor trees** to find these prime factors. This isn‚Äôt just a fun trick ‚Äî it builds your {{< glink number sense >}}: your ability to see patterns, understand how numbers are structured, and work confidently with them.

That number sense will come in handy later when you:

* Simplify fractions
* Solve equations
* Factor algebraic expressions
* Find common denominators

Let‚Äôs build a factor tree for **360** to see how it works.

---

#### Steps to Make a Factor Tree

1. Start with a number: 

```{mermaid}
%%| label: fig-mermaid-diagram
%%| fit-align: center
%%| fig-cap: " "
flowchart TB
    node_0("360")
```

2. Find any two numbers that multiply to give the number: $360 = 18 √ó 20$

```{mermaid}
%%| label: fig-mermaid-diagram
%%| fit-align: center
%%| fig-cap: " "
flowchart TB
    node_0("360")
    node_1_0_1("18")
    node_0 --- node_1_0_1
    node_1_1_1("20")
    node_0 --- node_1_1_1
```

3. Break each of those numbers down further:

   - $18 = 3 √ó 6$
   - $20 = 4 √ó 5$

```{mermaid}
%%| label: fig-mermaid-diagram
%%| fit-align: center
%%| fig-cap: " "
flowchart TB
    node_0("360")
    node_1_0_1("18")
    node_0 --- node_1_0_1
    node_1_0_2_0_2("3")
    node_1_0_1 --- node_1_0_2_0_2
    node_1_0_2_1_2("6")
    node_1_0_1 --- node_1_0_2_1_2
    node_1_1_1("20")
    node_0 --- node_1_1_1
    node_1_1_2_0_2("4")
    node_1_1_1 --- node_1_1_2_0_2
    node_1_1_2_1_2("5")
    node_1_1_1 --- node_1_1_2_1_2
```

4. Keep going until all branches end in **prime numbers** (numbers that can‚Äôt be factored anymore, like 2, 3, 5, 7...). We call the ends of the branches "leaves".

```{mermaid}
%%| label: fig-mermaid-diagram
%%| fit-align: center
%%| fig-cap: " "
    flowchart TB
    node_0("360")
    node_1_0_1("18")
    node_0 --- node_1_0_1
    node_1_0_2_0_2("3")
    node_1_0_1 --- node_1_0_2_0_2
    node_1_0_2_1_2("6")
    node_1_0_1 --- node_1_0_2_1_2
    node_1_0_2_1_3_0_3("2")
    node_1_0_2_1_2 --- node_1_0_2_1_3_0_3
    node_1_0_2_1_3_1_3("3")
    node_1_0_2_1_2 --- node_1_0_2_1_3_1_3
    node_1_1_1("20")
    node_0 --- node_1_1_1
    node_1_1_2_0_2("4")
    node_1_1_1 --- node_1_1_2_0_2
    node_1_1_2_0_3_0_3("2")
    node_1_1_2_0_2 --- node_1_1_2_0_3_0_3
    node_1_1_2_0_3_1_3("2")
    node_1_1_2_0_2 --- node_1_1_2_0_3_1_3
    node_1_1_2_1_2("5")
    node_1_1_1 --- node_1_1_2_1_2

    style node_1_1_2_1_2 stroke-width:4px,font-weight:bold;
    style node_1_1_2_0_3_1_3 stroke-width:4px,font-weight:bold;
    style node_1_1_2_0_3_0_3 stroke-width:4px,font-weight:bold;
    style node_1_0_2_1_3_1_3 stroke-width:4px,font-weight:bold;
    style node_1_0_2_1_3_0_3 stroke-width:4px,font-weight:bold;
    style node_1_0_2_0_2 stroke-width:4px,font-weight:bold;

```

5. The prime factorization is the {{< glink product >}} of the leaves of the tree: <br> 
$$2 * 2 * 2 * 3 * 3 * 5 = 360$$
This can be written more compactly by using the factor counts as exponents. There are three 2s and two 3s in this case and so we get...<br>
$$2^3 * 3^2 * 5 = 360$$

---

There are *many* factor trees for the number 360. For example, you could also have started with $360 = 3 * 120$.

```{mermaid}
%%| label: fig-mermaid-diagram
%%| fit-align: center
%%| fig-cap: " "
flowchart TB
    node_0("360")
    node_1_0_1("3")
    node_0 --- node_1_0_1
    node_1_1_1("120")
    node_0 --- node_1_1_1
    node_1_1_2_0_2("2")
    node_1_1_1 --- node_1_1_2_0_2
    node_1_1_2_1_2("60")
    node_1_1_1 --- node_1_1_2_1_2
    node_1_1_2_1_3_0_3("15")
    node_1_1_2_1_2 --- node_1_1_2_1_3_0_3
    node_1_1_2_1_3_0_4_0_4("5")
    node_1_1_2_1_3_0_3 --- node_1_1_2_1_3_0_4_0_4
    node_1_1_2_1_3_0_4_1_4("3")
    node_1_1_2_1_3_0_3 --- node_1_1_2_1_3_0_4_1_4
    node_1_1_2_1_3_1_3("4")
    node_1_1_2_1_2 --- node_1_1_2_1_3_1_3
    node_1_1_2_1_3_1_4_0_4("2")
    node_1_1_2_1_3_1_3 --- node_1_1_2_1_3_1_4_0_4
    node_1_1_2_1_3_1_4_1_4("2")
    node_1_1_2_1_3_1_3 --- node_1_1_2_1_3_1_4_1_4

    style node_1_0_1 stroke-width:4px,font-weight:bold;
    style node_1_1_2_0_2 stroke-width:4px,font-weight:bold;
    style node_1_1_2_1_3_0_4_1_4 stroke-width:4px,font-weight:bold;
    style node_1_1_2_1_3_0_4_0_4 stroke-width:4px,font-weight:bold;
    style node_1_1_2_1_3_1_4_0_4 stroke-width:4px,font-weight:bold;
    style node_1_1_2_1_3_1_4_1_4 stroke-width:4px,font-weight:bold;
```

There are still three 2s, two 3s, and one 5, so the prime factorization does not change!
$$2^3 * 3^2 * 5 = 360$$
As long as you end up with the same prime numbers, the tree is correct!

---

:::{.callout-tip title="Which factors should I start with?"}

There is no one right answer to this question. It depends on your goal. If your goal is finding easy numbers, you might start small.  Notice that 360 is {{< glink even >}} that means it is divisible by 2. We could divide by 2 and keep going that way.

```{mermaid}
%%| label: mermaid-diagram
%%| fit-align: center
%%| fig-cap: " "
flowchart TB
    node_0("360")
    node_1_0_1("2")
    node_0 --- node_1_0_1
    node_1_1_1("180")
    node_0 --- node_1_1_1
    node_1_1_2_0_2("2")
    node_1_1_1 --- node_1_1_2_0_2
    node_1_1_2_1_2("90")
    node_1_1_1 --- node_1_1_2_1_2
    node_1_1_2_1_3_0_3("2")
    node_1_1_2_1_2 --- node_1_1_2_1_3_0_3
    node_1_1_2_1_3_1_3("45")
    node_1_1_2_1_2 --- node_1_1_2_1_3_1_3
    node_1_1_2_1_3_1_4_0_4("3")
    node_1_1_2_1_3_1_3 --- node_1_1_2_1_3_1_4_0_4
    node_1_1_2_1_3_1_4_1_4("15")
    node_1_1_2_1_3_1_3 --- node_1_1_2_1_3_1_4_1_4
    node_1_1_2_1_3_1_4_1_5_0_5("3")
    node_1_1_2_1_3_1_4_1_4 --- node_1_1_2_1_3_1_4_1_5_0_5
    node_1_1_2_1_3_1_4_1_5_1_5("5")
    node_1_1_2_1_3_1_4_1_4 --- node_1_1_2_1_3_1_4_1_5_1_5

    style node_1_0_1 stroke-width:4px,font-weight:bold;
    style node_1_1_2_0_2 stroke-width:4px,font-weight:bold;
    style node_1_1_2_1_3_0_3 stroke-width:4px,font-weight:bold;
    style node_1_1_2_1_3_1_4_0_4 stroke-width:4px,font-weight:bold;
    style node_1_1_2_1_3_1_4_1_5_0_5 stroke-width:4px,font-weight:bold;
    style node_1_1_2_1_3_1_4_1_5_1_5 stroke-width:4px,font-weight:bold;
```

When you divide by the smallest (or biggest) factors, the tree tends to become deep. If you want smaller trees, you should start with factor pairs that are closer together like we did with the first factor tree for 360, splitting first with 18 and 20.

:::

**What About Negative Numbers?**

If the number is negative, factor out a -1 first. Here is one possible factor tree for -24:

```{mermaid}
%%| label: fig-mermaid-diagram
%%| fit-align: center
%%| fig-cap: " "
flowchart TB
    node_0("-24")
    node_1_0_1("-1")
    node_0 --- node_1_0_1
    node_1_1_1("24")
    node_0 --- node_1_1_1
    node_1_1_2_0_2("4")
    node_1_1_1 --- node_1_1_2_0_2
    node_1_1_2_0_3_0_3("2")
    node_1_1_2_0_2 --- node_1_1_2_0_3_0_3
    node_1_1_2_0_3_1_3("2")
    node_1_1_2_0_2 --- node_1_1_2_0_3_1_3
    node_1_1_2_1_2("6")
    node_1_1_1 --- node_1_1_2_1_2
    node_1_1_2_1_3_0_3("2")
    node_1_1_2_1_2 --- node_1_1_2_1_3_0_3
    node_1_1_2_1_3_1_3("3")
    node_1_1_2_1_2 --- node_1_1_2_1_3_1_3

    style node_1_0_1 stroke-width:4px,font-weight:bold;
    style node_1_1_2_0_3_0_3 stroke-width:4px,font-weight:bold;
    style node_1_1_2_0_3_1_3 stroke-width:4px,font-weight:bold;
    style node_1_1_2_1_3_0_3 stroke-width:4px,font-weight:bold;
    style node_1_1_2_1_3_1_3 stroke-width:4px,font-weight:bold;
```

So, the prime factorization of -24 is...

$$-1 * 2^3 * 3 = -24$$


This will come in handy later when we factor algebraic expressions like $-x^2 + 4x$. It‚Äôs often helpful to pull out a negative first!

**Feeling overwhelmed?**

If you struggle to come up with the factors for a number, you should check out the [factor chart](/resources/Factor-Chart_noprimes.pdf) in the resources section of this book. It shows all of the factor pairs for many composite numbers!


:::{.callout-note icon=false appearance="simple" collapse=true title="üß† Can you find at least one more factor tree for 360?"}

I have only shown you 3 of the 60 unique factor trees for 360!
:::
